key_points: The US State Department has announced a $10 million reward for information on the leaders of the cybercrime group DarkSide.
An additional reward of up to $5 million is offered for information leading to the arrest or conviction of anyone involved in DarkSide ransomware incidents.
This initiative is part of the US's efforts to combat the increasing trend of cyber-extortion attacks.
DarkSide is blamed by the US for a major cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline in May, leading to a shutdown.
The shutdown resulted in increased gas prices and fuel shortages in the southeastern US.
The FBI identifies DarkSide as a Russia-based group.
Colonial Pipeline paid nearly $5 million in Bitcoin to the hackers, with the US Justice Department later recovering about $2.3 million.
The world's largest meat processor, JBS, also reported paying $11 million in ransom to another Russian group, REvil.
US authorities reported $590 million in ransomware-related payments in the first half of 2021, a 42% increase over the entire year of 2020.
Ransomware cyber-extortion involves breaking into a network, encrypting data, and demanding cryptocurrency for decryption keys.
